Eugenia Casella Tavares de Mattos

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/7865166802385092
  • Última atualização do currículo em 01/02/2019

Graduada em Fisioterapia pela Universidade Federal de São Carlos no final do ano de 2000, com título de mestre defendido em 2003 e de doutora em 2009 em Neurociências e Comportamento pela Universidade de São Paulo. Tem 8 anos de experiência em docência em graduação e pos-graduação em fisioterapia. Desenvolveu diversas pesquisas em plasticidade neural com treinamento físico e fadiga. Após a especialização em Ergonomia, tem focado seus trabalhos em consultorias em Ergonomia na região do Vale do Paraíba e Docência no território nacional. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2016 - Atual
Effects of resistance training with instability on clinical outcomes, spinal mechanisms, and brain metrics in individuals with freezing of gait in Parkinson diseases?
Descrição: Freezing of gait (FOG) in Parkinson's disease (PD) affects approximately 26% of individuals with moderate PD and 80% of individuals with severe PD, and it is one of the most common causes of falls, dependency, and poor quality of life. FOG is because of impaired coupling between postural and locomotor components that result in reduced connectivity in frontal motor regions, prefrontal cortices, and subcortical areas. Moreover, deficits in spinal control and cognitive dysfunction seem to contribute to FOG. Thus, studies should investigate the effects of powerful innovative therapeutic interventions on central, spinal and cognitive outcomes, as pharmacological, surgical and therapeutic interventions (e.g., use of external cues) do not seem to effectively decrease FOG episodes. Therefore, the objective of this randomized controlled trial will be to examine the effects of 12 weeks of resistance training with instability (RTI) on clinical outcomes, spinal mechanisms, and cerebral metrics of individuals with FOG between stages 3 and 4 of the PD. Thirty individuals (will be tested and trained in the "on" medication state) that meet the inclusion criteria will be randomized into two groups: nonexercising control group (CG) and RTI group (RTIG). Both groups will go twice a week on nonconsecutive days to the exercise facility. While the CG will attend lectures on disease education, RTIG will perform only exercises with high motor complexity (i.e., five progressive resistance exercises concomitantly with progressive unstable devices). The following outcomes will be assessed before and after the intervention: 1) Clinical frequency and duration of FOG vertical acceleration of the lower limb (primary outcome), gait parameters cadence, speed, Projetos de pesquisa toe clearance, stride length and gait variability, severity of FOG scores of the New Freezing of Gait Questionnaire [NFOGQ] and of the Unified Parkinson?s Disease Rating Scale part 14 [UPDRS14], amplitude and time of anticipatory postural adjustments during a step initiation task while standing on the force platform, attention and processing speed (score Digit Symbol Substitution Test), executive function (Trail Making Test score), and quality of life (score of Questionnaire Parkinson's disease [PDQ39]) ; 2) Spinal Mechanisms presynaptic and reciprocal inhibitions during a task of step initiating while standing on the force platform; 3) Brain Metrics the BOLD (Blood Oxygenation Level Dependent) signal intensity and functional connectivity of cortical and subcortical areas during a leg lifting task, which simulates a step, as assessed by functional magnetic resonance imaging. Appropriate statistical analysis will be conducted to verify the effect of RTI on clinical outcomes, spinal mechanism, and brain metrics after 12 weeks..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Mestrado acadêmico: (3) .

Integrantes: Eugenia Casella Tavares de Mattos - Integrante / UGRINOWITSCH, CARLOS - Coordenador / carla silva batista - Integrante / Daniel Motie Corcos - Integrante.
2014 - 2016

2012 - Atual
Influence of resistance training with instability on intracellular mechanisms associated with the muscle weakness in MSA patients
Descrição: The specific cause of muscle weakness in patients with Parkinson's disease is not known, and studies have questioned whether the source of muscle weakness is the central or peripheral nervous system, and is intrinsic to the disease or a secondary phenomenon, since muscle weakness is present in all stages of Parkinson's disease. Muscle atrophy, significant loss of muscle mass, is characterized by a decrease in protein content, reduction in fiber diameter, decreased strength and low fatigue resistance due to an imbalance between the process of protein synthesis and degradation. Additionally, some studies have found Skeletal muscle mitochondrial dysfunction in PD. In animal models, this dysfunction may lead to increased oxidative stress which increases expression of the different components of protein degradation system, for example, the system ATPdependent ubiquitinproteasome. The ubiquitinproteasome system is responsible for degrading 90% of oxidized and ubiquitinated cellular proteins. In fact, the brains of parkinsonian mitochondrial dysfunction affects the ubiquitin proteasome system dependent due to increased oxidative stress causes oxidative damage to proteins reducing the ATP needed for normal function of the ubiquitin proteasome system and neurodegeneration well. Given the parallels between the brain and muscle of PD, since they are postmitotic tissues and mitochondrial dysfunction found in these tissues, we believe that this dysfunction may also lead to increased oxidative stress in muscle. However, it is still unknown whether this increase oxidative contributes to increase of protein degradation in skeletal muscle of parkinsonian leading to possible muscle atrophy...
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (1) / Especialização: (1) / Mestrado acadêmico: (2) / Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Eugenia Casella Tavares de Mattos - Integrante / UGRINOWITSCH, CARLOS - Integrante / carla silva batista - Coordenador / Daniel Motie Corcos - Integrante / Fay Horak - Integrante / Daniel Boari Coelho - Integrante / Edson Amaro Júnior - Integrante / Luis Augusto Teixeira - Integrante / Andrea Cristina de Lima Pardini - Integrante.
2010 - 2015
Adaptações neuromusculares a diferentes tipos de treinos em pacientes com Doença de Parkinson
Descrição: Projeto amplo que envolve avaliação de muitas variáveis neurais da população idosa com Parkinson e comparação após período de treinamento com e sem instabilidade para identificar o melhor tipo de treino para esta população..
Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Doutorado: (1) .

Integrantes: Eugenia Casella Tavares de Mattos - Integrante / Carla Silva Batista - Integrante / Carlos UGRINOWITSCH - Coordenador.
2010 - 2014

Situação: Concluído; Natureza: Pesquisa.
